### Enhanced Information (For Contextual Support):
Penicillin G is the drug of choice for treating Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, as recommended by the CDC. It is effective at all stages of the disease due to its bactericidal effect, which involves disrupting the bacterial cell wall synthesis. For individuals allergic to penicillin, Doxycycline serves as an alternative treatment, though it is less effective than Penicillin G. Other antibiotics like Azithromycin and Tetracycline are also used in some cases but are generally less preferred due to potential resistance and side effects. The evidence path confirming Treponema pallidum as the cause of syphilis supports the use of these antibiotics, particularly emphasizing the primary role of Penicillin G in treatment.
